definitions: concealed from ordinary knowledge or view; not easily understood or detected
relating to supernatural, mystical, or magical beliefs, practices, or phenomena
examples: The disease had occult symptoms that were hard to diagnose
Scientists discovered occult blood in the patient's test results
She studied occult practices from ancient civilizations
The bookstore had a section devoted to occult literature

definitions: connected with or resulting from one's job, profession, or regular employment
examples: The carpenter developed occupational injuries from years of manual labor
Occupational therapy helped her return to work after the accident

definitions: being used by someone; filled with people or things that are there
having one's time or attention completely taken up by something
examples: All the hotel rooms were occupied during the festival
The occupied territories had strict border controls
She kept herself occupied with reading during the long flight
The children were occupied with their new toys all afternoon

definitions: designed or suitable for traveling on the ocean, especially for long voyages
examples: The oceangoing vessel could withstand rough Atlantic storms
They purchased an oceangoing yacht for their world tour

definitions: of, relating to, or characteristic of the ocean or oceans in general
examples: The oceanic currents affect global weather patterns significantly
Marine biologists study oceanic ecosystems and their complex food chains

definitions: having a yellowish-brown or reddish-brown earth tone color like the natural pigment
examples: The artist painted the desert landscape in ochre tones
The old building had ochre walls that glowed in sunset

definitions: having eight straight sides and eight angles in geometric form
examples: The octagonal stop sign is recognized worldwide for traffic control
They built an octagonal gazebo in the center of the garden

definitions: of or connected with the eyes or the sense of sight
examples: The doctor performed an ocular examination to check vision health
Ocular muscles control the movement and focusing of our eyes

definitions: extremely unpleasant, repulsive, or deserving of hatred and strong dislike
examples: His odious behavior at the party offended all the guests
The dictator's odious crimes against humanity shocked the world

definitions: having no odor or scent that can be detected by the sense of smell
examples: Carbon monoxide is a dangerous odorless gas that requires detectors
The new paint was advertised as completely odorless and non-toxic

definitions: unconventional, unusual, or different from what is generally expected or accepted
examples: She had an offbeat sense of humor that not everyone appreciated
The restaurant's offbeat decor attracted artists and creative types

definitions: caused to feel upset, annoyed, or resentful by someone's words or actions
examples: He felt deeply offended by her thoughtless remarks about his work
The offended customer demanded to speak with the store manager

definitions: causing displeasure, anger, or resentment; responsible for wrongdoing or violation
examples: The editor removed the offending paragraph from the article
Police identified the offending vehicle that caused the accident

definitions: situated at sea some distance from the shore or coastline
located or based in a foreign country, especially for financial purposes
examples: The offshore oil rig operated twenty miles from the coast
Strong offshore winds made sailing conditions challenging for beginners
Many companies use offshore banking to manage international funds
The firm moved its manufacturing to offshore facilities in Asia

definitions: in an illegal position ahead of the ball or play in certain sports
examples: The goal was disallowed because the striker was offside
The referee's offside call stopped the promising attack immediately

definitions: happening or located away from the area of a stage visible to audience
examples: The actors waited offstage for their cue to enter
We could hear offstage noises during the quiet scene

definitions: covered, treated, or lubricated with oil for protection or smooth operation
examples: The well-oiled machine ran smoothly without any squeaking sounds
She kept her leather boots oiled to prevent cracking

definitions: containing oil or covered with oil; greasy in texture or appearance
unpleasantly smooth, ingratiating, or servile in manner or speech
examples: His oily skin required special cleansing products twice daily
The mechanic's oily hands left marks on the steering wheel
The salesman's oily charm made customers suspicious of his motives
She distrusted his oily compliments and false flattery

definitions: of or from former times, especially the distant past; ancient
examples: In olden days, people traveled by horse and carriage
Grandmother told stories of the olden times before electricity

definitions: having lived or existed for a greater length of time; more advanced in age
examples: His older sister graduated from college three years before him
The older building needed more maintenance than newer ones

definitions: of or relating to the sense of smell or the organs of smell
examples: Dogs have highly developed olfactory abilities for tracking scents
The olfactory nerves send smell signals directly to the brain

definitions: relating to government by a small group of powerful people or families
examples: The oligarchic system concentrated wealth among elite families
Critics argued the country had become oligarchic rather than democratic

definitions: godlike in manner or bearing; majestic, aloof, or superior
of or relating to the Olympic Games or Mount Olympus
examples: She maintained an olympian detachment from office politics
His olympian calm during the crisis impressed everyone present
The olympian athletes trained for years before the games
Ancient Greeks believed olympian gods lived on Mount Olympus

definitions: giving the impression that something bad or unpleasant is going to happen
examples: Dark ominous clouds gathered before the devastating storm arrived
The ominous silence in the room made everyone feel uneasy

definitions: having unlimited or very great power; able to do anything
examples: Many religions describe their deity as omnipotent and all-knowing
The dictator believed himself omnipotent until the revolution began

definitions: present everywhere at the same time; constantly encountered or widespread
examples: Smartphones have become omnipresent in modern society
The omnipresent security cameras monitored every corner

definitions: knowing everything; having unlimited knowledge or understanding
examples: The omniscient narrator knew every character's thoughts and secrets
No human being can be truly omniscient about the future

definitions: eating both plant and animal food; feeding on various kinds of food
examples: Bears are omnivorous animals that eat fish, berries, and insects
Her omnivorous reading habits included everything from classics to comics

definitions: approaching from the front; moving toward one
examples: The driver swerved to avoid the oncoming traffic
She saw the oncoming storm and hurried inside for shelter

definitions: involving heavy obligations or burdens; causing hardship or difficulty
examples: The onerous task of reviewing thousands of documents took months
They found the contract terms too onerous to accept

definitions: former; having been something specified in the past but not now
examples: The onetime champion struggled to regain his former glory
Her onetime friend had become her biggest business rival

definitions: moving toward or located on the shore from the sea
situated or operating within one's own country rather than abroad
examples: Onshore winds brought cooler temperatures to the coastal area
The onshore facilities processed oil from offshore platforms
The company decided to bring onshore jobs back from overseas
Onshore banking provided more regulatory protection for customers

definitions: in a legal position in relation to the ball in certain sports
examples: The player stayed onside to receive the winning pass
The referee confirmed the striker was onside when scoring

definitions: taking place on the area of a theater stage visible to the audience
examples: Her onstage presence captivated the entire audience
The actors remained onstage during the entire first act

definitions: not allowing light to pass through; not transparent or translucent
hard to understand or explain; not clear or lucid
examples: The opaque glass windows provided privacy from outside viewers
She painted the jar with opaque paint to block light
His opaque writing style confused many readers
The company's opaque financial statements raised investor concerns

definitions: having been made accessible or available; not closed or blocked
examples: The newly opened restaurant attracted crowds of curious diners
She left the opened window to let fresh air circulate

definitions: able to be used or operated; in working order
able to be treated by surgical operation
examples: The old computer was still operable despite its age
All emergency exits must remain operable during business hours
The tumor was operable and could be removed safely
Doctors determined the condition was operable with minimal risk

definitions: of, relating to, or characteristic of opera; dramatic or exaggerated
examples: Her operatic voice filled the concert hall with powerful sound
His operatic gestures seemed excessive for normal conversation

definitions: ready for use; able to function properly; relating to operation of business
examples: The new subway line became operational after years of construction
All operational decisions required approval from senior management

definitions: functioning effectively; having effect or being in operation
most significant or relevant in a particular situation
examples: The security system remained operative throughout the power outage
Several operative factors contributed to the project's success
Trust was the operative word in their business relationship
The operative principle here is maintaining customer satisfaction

definitions: having and expressing strong opinions in an assertive, often arrogant way
examples: His opinionated comments during meetings annoyed his quieter colleagues
She was too opinionated to consider alternative viewpoints

definitions: occurring at a favorable or useful time; well-timed for maximum advantage
examples: Her job offer came at an opportune moment in his career
They waited for an opportune time to announce the merger

definitions: taking advantage of opportunities with little regard for principles or consequences
examples: The opportunist politician changed positions to gain more votes
Critics called him an opportunist who befriended people for personal gain

definitions: exploiting immediate opportunities, especially with little regard for principles or long-term consequences
examples: Opportunistic investors bought stocks during the market crash
The opportunistic bacteria infected patients with weakened immune systems

definitions: in conflict or competition with; situated on opposite sides
examples: The opposing teams shook hands after the intense match
Opposing viewpoints were presented during the heated debate

definitions: subjected to harsh and unjust treatment or control by authority
examples: The oppressed workers organized protests for better conditions
Throughout history, oppressed peoples have fought for their freedom

definitions: unjustly inflicting hardship and constraint on others through abuse of authority
weighing heavily on the mind or spirits; causing discomfort
examples: The oppressive regime restricted freedom of speech and assembly
Citizens rebelled against oppressive laws that limited their rights
The oppressive heat made outdoor work nearly impossible
An oppressive silence filled the room after the announcement

definitions: of or relating to the eye or vision
examples: The optic nerve transmits visual information to the brain
Damage to optic fibers can result in vision loss

definitions: relating to sight, light, or the physical properties of light and vision
examples: The optical illusion made parallel lines appear curved
She needed optical correction to improve her nearsighted vision
